states.content: Can conventional mechanisms of injury alone account for observed effects?
Treat as conventional mass-casualty incident (MCI), maintain safety at the scene, remain vigilant for possible CWA or radiation
Consider chemical-warfare agents (CWAs), maintain safety at the scene, don personal protective equipment (PPE), assess victims
Increased secretions or muscle effects (fasciculations, weakness, paralysis), with or without miosis
Bradypnea or apnea
Unlikely to be CWA; reassess for conventional injuries and watch for delayed effects of CWAs
Gasping, collapse, and seizures with or without cyanosis
Confusion
Assume nerve agent; administer atropine and pralidoxime, provide airway support and spot decontamination
Consider asphyxiant; administer cyanide antidote, provide airway support and spot decontamination
Sedation
Consider anesthetic agent (manage airway if needed; if unsure, administer naloxone)
Miosis
Respiratory noise (coughing, hoarseness, stridor)
Consider opioid agent; administer naloxone, provide airway support and spot decontamination
Mydriasis, dry skin, elevated temperature
Consider central-compartment (large-airway) pulmonary agent
Delayed-onset shortness of breath or chest tightness
Consider anticholinergic agent
Eye, throat, or skin pain
Diplopia, descending paralysis, dysphagia, and mydriasis
Consider peripheral-compartment (small-airways) pulmonary agent
Consider vesicant, caustic or riot-control agent, or T-2 toxin
Skin blistering
Consider botulinum toxin
